title: Jeweler sentenced to three weeks in college bribery scheme
text:
The owner of a California jewelry store business has been sentenced to three weeks in prison for paying $15,000 to rig her son's ACT exam and falsely list him as a a racial minority on college applications.

Marjorie Klapper, 51, had earlier pleaded guilty to a single count of fraud and conspiracy for her role in what prosecutors say is the largest college admissions scam uncovered in the United States.

She admitted to paying $15,000 to mastermind William 'Rick' Singer to have a corrupt test proctor secretly correct her son's answers on his ACT college entrance exam back in 2017.

Klapper was also accused of falsely listing her son as African American and Hispanic on college applications to increase his chances of getting admitted.

Marjorie Klapper, 51, was sentenced to three weeks in prison on Wednesday for paying $15,000 to rig her son's ACT exam and falsely list him as a racial minority on college applications

She also indicated that he was the first in his family to attend college even though both Klapper and her husband graduated from college.

Singer pleaded guilty in March for masterminding the scheme.

Mark Riddell, the proctor that was used in the Klapper case, has also pleaded guilty. He was a counselor at a Florida private school who secretly took SAT and ACT exams for the children of Singer's clients or corrected their answers.

Prosecutors said that Klapper's son used the fraudulent ACT score he received to apply to universities in Arizona, California, Colorado and elsewhere.

In court documents, Klapper's lawyers said the scheme's ringleaders listed her son as a racial minority without her knowledge.

They said she pursued the scheme because she wanted her son, who has a learning disability, to feel like a 'regular' student.

'Mrs Klapper's motives were maternal but her execution misguided and illegal,' her lawyers wrote.

Klapper had earlier pleaded guilty to a single count of fraud and conspiracy for her role in what prosecutors say is the largest college admissions scam uncovered in the United States

Klapper admitted to paying $15,000 to mastermind William 'Rick' Singer to have a corrupt test proctor secretly correct her son's answers on his ACT college entrance exam back in 2017

California business records list Klapper as a co-owner of M&M Bling, a jewelry business in Los Altos, California.

Her lawyers said she has 'made a modest income by selling jewelry'.

Prosecutors had asked for a sentence of four months in prison, arguing that by lying on her son's applications, Klapper 'increased the likelihood that her fraud would come at the expense of an actual minority candidate'.

She is the ninth parent to be sentenced in the widespread college bribery scheme involving dozens of wealthy and famous parents.

Seven others were dealt prison terms, ranging from 14 days to 5 months.

Actress Felicity Huffman, who was sentenced to 14 days, reported to a federal prison in California on Wednesday to begin her sentence.

A total of 15 parents have pleaded guilty, while 19 are contesting the charges, including 'Full House' actress Lori Loughlin and her fashion designer husband, Mossimo Giannulli, who are accused of paying $500,000 to get their two daughters into the University of Southern California as fake athletes.

Trials are expected to begin in 2020.
